Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: looking at the system log, each line has a timestamp, action type, application, and window title. The challenge is to group these into coherent cases. Cases should represent logical units of work, like editing a document or handling an email.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: I need to identify when a user starts working on a specific document or task. For example, the user starts with Document1.docx in Word, types, saves, then switches to Chrome to reply to an email. Then switches to Adobe, then Excel, and back.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: perhaps each document edit is a separate case? Or maybe the entire workflow from starting Document1 to closing it, then opening Quarterly_Report is separate.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: the case is the main document being worked on. So when the user is working on Document1.docx, thats Case 1. Then, when they switch to Chrome to reply to an email, thats an activity in Case 1. Then Adobe and Excel are also activities in Case 1.

Name: Backtracking - IND
Text: Alternatively, each application window is a separate case? But that might not make sense. Alternatively, the case is the users work session. But the session starts at 8:59:50 and ends at 9:08:15. However, the user is working on multiple documents and applications.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Let me check the timestamps again. Looking at the events: 1. 8:59:50 - FOCUS on Quarterly_Report.docx 2. 9:00:00 - FOCUS on Document1.docx 3. Then typing, saving, switching to Chrome, replying to email, switching to Adobe, then Excel, then back to Document1.docx, adding reference, saving, closing, then opening Quarterly_Report.docx.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: when a new document is focused, thats the start of a case. So the case ID would be based on the document name. But need to check if there are multiple instances of the same document.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Now, activity naming. The raw actions are FOCUS, TYPING, SWITCH, CLICK, SCROLL, HIGHLIGHT, SAVE, CLOSE. Need to translate these into higher-level activities. For example, FOCUS: Open Document TYPING: Edit Content SAVE: Save Document SWITCH: Switch Application CLICK: Open Email, Reply to Email, Send Email SCROLL: Review Content HIGHLIGHT: Highlight Text CLOSE: Close Document.
